answers.answer: I am not a physician, but a volunteer and the mom of a type 1 and the daughter of a type 2 diabetic.  I would suggest that if the doctor cannot figure it out how to control these low blood sugars ; get a second or third opinion.  It seems that you were told that it is a result of the bypass. The reason you feel better after eating carbs is that they are bringing up your blood sugar. That is how you treat a low blood sugar especially if you are a diabetic.Since you have had a severe low, I would suggest that you ask your doctor if you should have a prescription for glucagons. This is a shot that gets your blood sugar up. Most EMTs and ambulance crops do not carry this drug.I hope this helps, Lease check back with us again.

question: I had a gastric by-pass revision in 1992. So I don't know if that has anything to do with having low blood sugar problems today. I get tested every year for diabetes, (sister & mother have it). Everytime the test comes back negative. Yet on a regular basis I experience low blood sugar. It will hit me any time, any where unexpectedly. I know its coming on, because I get an odd, hollow hungry feeling in the pit of my stomach. Then the shakes start, and then I'll start to sweat. I never skip breakfast anymore, because I nearly collapsed at work after doing that. The worst happened at home when I was nearly unconscious, when my son called 911. My blood sugar then, was 40, the EMT's told me. As soon as I eat something with substance, bread/meat/glass of milk, etc, then I was okay. But my doctor has never been able to diagnose me with diabetes. Earlier on, after the gastric bypass the doctors then, told me the low bloodsugar was due to the bypass. I'm very concerned that my health may become severely affected because my blood sugar is not staying normal. What do you suggest for tests that would give the doctor the best results? I have been tested for diabetes before eating, and after eating, each time the test was negative. Thank you
